column11: Review Text
Beautiful and calm memories of the Second World War. Immaculate and peaceful gardens, clean and well cared for headstones

A place which was missing by many people in and out of Kandy.,  Commonwealth War Cemetery Kandy or Kandy war cemetery is maintained to pay the tribute to the 203 British Empire soldiers who sacrify  their life during the World War I and II. This place is very nicely maintained. As per the Memorial Inscription., there are 203 buried consisting of: 107 British, 35 East Africans, 26 Sri Lankans, 23 Indians, 6 Canadians, 3 Italians, 1 Frenchman and 2 unidentified persons.  151 were army, 32 were air force, 16 were navy, another 2 represent merchant navy and national fire service respectively and 2 were unidentified. The place was well maintained and full of greenery with flowers.  Appriciate and Thanks to the commonwealth committee which maintain this place.

A friend and I spent a very peaceful morning at this cemetery. It is immaculately maintained, with manicured gardens that create a serene and respectful atmosphere. The quiet beauty of the surroundings made it a meaningful and contemplative visit.
A cemetery where the remains of people who participated in the 2nd out of the world lie. The place is very nice and well maintained. You can walk around, sit on benches and read the memorial plaques.

A friend and I spent a very peaceful morning at this cemetery. It is immaculately maintained with manicured gardens. There are benches to sit on to take some time in reflection of gratitude for all the service personnel who were killed in WW II and a soldier who died in WW I.
Such a peaceful and well maintained cemetery with a beautiful garden and thr tombstone there. A must see to visit this cemetery.  Such lovely flowers and the upkeep is good too

Always sobering to visit a cemetery and especially when those buried there died young and for their country. Japan bombed Sri Lanka twice but never invaded. The man looking after the gardens is very knowledgeable and can speak with authority on the stories behind the graves. The only female buried there was one of the brave female pilots who delivered planes to the airfields. Open daily 7 am to 4 pm

column11: Kandy War Cemetery, located in Kandy, Sri Lanka, is a poignant and well-maintained site dedicated to the memory of soldiers who died during World War II. Here's an overview based on common feedback from visitors
Lovely spot of calm quiet honouring commonwealth soldiers, airforce and navy who lost their lives defending Ceylon in WW2. The cemetery is beautifully cared for.

Kandy War Cemetery Having visited Sri Lanka several times, one of the places that I wanted to visit was a CWGC Cemetery, on our recent visit in February 2024, this wish was fulfilled. What can I say, a beautiful place, which was very peaceful and the grounds are kept immaculately. We were greeted by one of the  staff who tend these gardens on a daily basis, they were very knowledgeable, giving us an insight about the numerous headstones. Well worth a visit for the contemplative hour away from the bustling city.

Beautifully maintained cemetery within a lovely setting - the keeper can direct you to various graves - and the diversity of nationalities who fought against dictators many miles from home is sobering in these times .

It is a small cemetery dedicated to foreign soldiers who died during the Second World War. Reading the names and other information on the headstones, I noted that most of them died young. I wondered why their remains were not taken back to their own countries. The garden is well maintained. The grass/lawn has been cut short, flowering plants surround the area, and there is a big cross hanging at the center. I enjoyed my brief visit here.

Visited here early morning and was given a guided tour by the head gardener who clearly has a great love for the cemetery and who recounted  stories of many of the brave men and women buried there. The cemetery is beautifully maintained and well worth a visit to pay our respects to the war dead.

Stopped off en route from our day long tour of Kandy. What a wonderful place of rest for these servicemen and woman x1 who lost their lives during the war years. So well kept by the war commission,  immaculate gardens-the head of which was a charming knowledgeable worker that wished to engage and gain more insight into the history of the 2 nd world war from a visitors point of view. Peaceful tranquil and thought provoking. Humbling to say the least.
Very well maintained World War II military cemetery. Beautiful, calm and peaceful place.. A grave of a French soldier ðŸ‡«ðŸ‡·

Probably one of the best settings for a war cemetery that I have visited. Beautifully maintained. Incredibly peaceful. Head gardener shared a lot of information and facts and those buried there. Left with a sense of intense gratitude for the sacrifice the men and women buried in this beautiful place made.

Commonwealth War Cemetery Kandy, formerly known as the Pitakande Military Cemetery, is a British military cemetery in Kandy, Sri Lanka, for soldiers of the British Empire who were killed during World War II as well as a soldier who died during World War I. Calm and cool place to visit in Kandy city. Attractive place.

A beautiful resting place for young men who died in war. So many of them in their early 20's. Many are buried here far from their homes in East Africa, UK, Canada, Australia and even Italy. A reminder of the wastefulness of war, and the loss as we watch another one unfold in Ukraine. Will we never learn? Lest we forget... ðŸ’œ

Peaceful common wealth war cemetery - which unusually provides a resting place for a few Ceylon, french and Italian soldiers too (amongst the British, the Canadians and the Americans). If you are lucky enough to bump into the head gardener, do take the time to say â€˜hiâ€™ and he will give you a tour, sharing some great stories about the soldiers buried here. The gardens are stunning and the place is well looked after. Really worth a visit if you are in the area.

Common wealth war cemetery of Kandy is also known as Kandy war cemetery. It is a nice peaceful place. This cemetery is dedicated for for soldiers of the British Empire who were killed during World War II as well as a soldier who died during World War I. It is situated at Deveni Rajasinghe Mawatha. No entrance fees for the place.
This is a short distance from the Temple and well worth the experience. Make sure that you find Charles, the caretaker, to give you an informative tour and give him a tip since this site is free.

Thanks to our tuk-tuk driver, Jenudeen, we visited this beautiful little cemetery. We would never have known about it nor visited it if he hadn't shown us. It's not huge, which means you can pay every grave the respect it is due by visiting and looking at the names of all the men buried here. It is genuinely moving to see the graves of Christians, Muslims, Buddhists, Hindu, Jew and Sikhs side by side. A sad reminder that in death, we are all equal. The garden is impeccably kept, and it is one of the prettiest graveyards you will ever see. Worth taking the time to visit and experience some tranquillity.

Even though he's a little out of town, he's easy to get to in tuk-tuk. It is a really peaceful and quiet place, they have kept it in very good condition, so it is beautiful. A haven of peace in the busy Kandy

We were visiting a cultural show and went past this war cemetery and I asked the driver to stop. It looks locked but access is via a small gate and you can then spend some time in quiet solitude looking at the young men that sacrificed their lives during the war. I was the only person there. The cemetery is in excellent condition being looked after by the graves commission. If you have been to any of the WW1 graves in France and Belgium then this is similar although on a small scale. The guide who had been taking guests to the cultural show had never been asked to stop there before. Totally recommended to remember those that fought to allow you to go on holiday.

We happened upon the century on a walk. Hidden away but so beautiful and well kept as all Commonwealth cemeteries are. Peaceful and calm resting place. Worth more than a few moments to visit the individual graves of those who served and gave their lives. We shall remember them! So glad we had this time with them.

This is a really lovely spot to reflect on lives lost in war. It's interesting to see all the nationalities, ranks, religions all mingled together in this beautifully maintained cemetery. It doesn't take long to visit and is definitely worth a look.
remembering those who died in the last 2 wars brought a different perspective to our trip. Worth the visit
Walk into nostalgia. This cemetery is located near a beautiful river. This cemetery is maintained by the British War graves commission.

We went into the war gardens en route to see the Buddha. It is a stunning garden, well maintained with amazing planting and vibrant colours set amongst the memorial stones. The gardens also has signage to explain who lost their lives and who is laid to rest in the cemetery.

Came to pay my respects to the two RAMC soldiers who are buried here.  I've been to several War Cemetries and like this one, they are always well maintained.  I'm always amazed at the far flung places the British military served in. RIP.

A well deserved place for the ones who rest there. diffrent nationalities  who fought togather and noe rest togather, The place is well maintained The Gardner deserves the best treatment. A must visit palce in Kandy
Well maintained and beautiful spot. a real tribute to the soldiers buried here. It feels really peaceful

Arrived when the gates should have been opened but the caretaker obviously went home early. Graves very well maintained and memorials moving - helped to keep everything in perspective. Saddened that so many died so young but always the case when visiting these sites
Worth a quick visit to appreciate this stunning Cemetary. What an amazing way to commemorate those who were lost.
A fitting tribute to the men and 2 women of all nationalities who gave their lives so that we may be free.

I went on a morning hike to Kandy View Point and visited the Bahiravakanda Vihara Buddha Temple. While on my way down, I detoured and followed the road on the right instead of going back to my original starting point. I thought I would be able to reach the main road of Kandy city easily but I was wrong. I kept walking and walking and the road did not lead me to the city at the base of the mountain. About an hour walk, I saw a signboard which stated 200 m ahead is the Commonwealth War Cemetery. Since I was near this attraction, I decided to detour and visit this War Cemetery. It was free entrance. There was no one in the cemetery except me. The garden where the tombstones were erected was well manicured and beautifully maintained like a golf course. As the morning sun shone down on the tombs, I read the inscriptions on the tombs and found most died during the World War II period. I understand that the cemetery was a resting place for those who sacrificed their lives in defending Sri Lanka during the Second World War. Wikipedia indicates that there were 203 buried here. Most of them were British and only 26 of them were Sri Lankans. It reminded me of the Kranji Memorial Cemetery in Singapore. But the Japanese Imperialists conquered Singapore and the tyranny lasted for 3 years and 8 months. Sri Lanka did not suffer the same fate as Singapore. The Japanese only sabotaged certain parts of Sri Lanka with air raids but did not occupy the island. For those who perished, most died of sickness and accidents. The Second World War was a war between the Imperialists. The soldiers who died were defending the British Empire not protecting an independent country. The War Cemetery holds little significance for the locals. It was just a memorial ground for the relatives of those British soldiers to visit the graves and remember the dead. The surrounding scenery near to the Cemetery was gorgeous with waterfalls and lush greenery. It is a good hiking ground exploring the inner beauty of Kandy.

Was so moved to see this beautifully maintained war memorial in this wonderful location. The last sleep of this brave hearts couldn't have been at a better place. So many soldiers around the glove has found there eternal home here. Full gratitude for those who are maintaining this place.
Has all the dignity one expects of CWGC cemetries, but with a particularly beautiful setting.  The head gardner is eager to point our particularly graves that tell an interesting story
Extremely well looked after in a very peaceful and beautiful place. Well worth taking the time to show respect to all the different soldiers nationalities buried there.
This is a Cemetery of soldiers of many countries. Not a tourist attraction. You can give it s miss nothing much.

This is a great place to visit and see how well looked after our fallen soldiers are. The gardens are beautifully kept and the gardeners are friendly and chatty. A sad reminder of how many young lives were lost during the conflicts.
This beautifully maintained war cemetery is a moving reminder of those from the Commonwealth who died during and immediately after World War II.

I've never been to a Commonwealth War Grave site before, but we called in on the way back to our hotel after touring the main sites of Kandy. It is a strange and moving experience wandering amongst the 100+? gravestones of service men and women from around the world, it is difficult  to grasp almost 75 years after WW2 how many nationalities were swept up in the war and died in or near Sri Lanka from all over the old British Empire and beyond. The number of Regiments represented here is truly surprising - especially when you consider that S-L was considered  a safe posting with no land fighting and maybe a few small air raids, so I guess that in reality many of those buried here may have died  from disease, accident etc --- but so far from home ! Kept beautifully - well worth a visit if your hotel is on that side of town
Good and quite place - well made lawns and garden with memorials of soldiers who laid down their lives,  (1939 - 1945) Stop for respect.

Absolutely stunning little cemetery with approx 250 memorial stones of soldiers. TIP: Ask your driver to stop for a moment on the way to Kandy if your hotel is outside town. You'll find a moment of absolute peace.
dedicated to soldiers of different countries who died in world war 2 this is a very calm and relaxing place.landscape is good.
A little off the beaten track but well worth a trip in a tuk tuk. Located in a peaceful corner of Kandy is the impeccably kept graveyard which brings back WW2 as you walk around the gravestones.
British Commonwealth war graves commission maintains this place where many commonwealth soldiers in the British Colonies are buried.

The commonwealth war graves are so beautifully kept, it is located in a peaceful spot of Kandy. The graves  have beautiful flowers and the grass is cut perfectly. The graves are very much worth a quick visit to pay respects and admire the beauty and the peacefulness.
Never knew this place existed until our the the driver took us there. Very well looked after and sad to see so many names there.
Amazing experience! And we were able to place a wreath on the tomb of the unknown soldier. Very humbling experience and I know my friends will never forget that day.
Wonderful place to visit and reflect, gardens and graves immaculately kept. Please visit this oasis of calm

Off the beaten track but for some this will be another reminder of the great work done by the Commonwealth Graves. About 200 serviceman lie here of various nationalties, half British. The caretaker maintains the hillside site with individual bushes on every grave beautifully, and also is very knowledgeable

Itâ€™s not a tourist site,but itâ€™s a beautiful presented war grave cemetery. Well manicured lawns and flowers throughout this haven of greenery. The gardener was so proud to give you a tour of what must be his pride and joy. A respectful place ....

This is a very sweet cemetery, containing the graves of Ceylonese and Allied soldiers beautifully maintained. It is on a fairly steep hill and requires a little non strenuous walking. I was very happy that I sought it out.

The is beautifully maintained and a lovely quiet place. There is a gardener who maintains the graves and does, it has to be said, hang around for a tip, but actually he does a brilliant job and so deserves it!
Quite an experience to see such beautifully maintained war cemetery. It does bring a lump to your throat.

British Empire who were killed during World War I and II , 203 buried consisting of: 107 British, 35 East Africans, 26 Sri Lankans, 23 Indians, 6 Canadians, 3 Italians, 1 Frenchman and 2 unidentified persons,[2] Of the 203 dead, 151 were army, 32 were air force, 16 were navy, 2 were unidentified, 1 was merchant navy and 1 was from the national fire service.

We happened on the cemetery enroute to our hotel in Kandy thanks to a detour our driver took to avoid traffic. We have visited many war cemeteries in France and Belgium but this was exceptionally well kept, a total credit to the gardener who happened to be there and was so proud to talk to us about the men and women buried there. It is well worth the effort to find it .

This is one of 3 war cemeteries in Sri Lanka for casualties of WW2. Others are in Colombo & near Trincomalee. This particular cemetery has casualties during the attacks on Trincomalee & Colombo harbours. The cemetery is under the watch of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in England (as are the others in Sri Lanka) & the maintenance is done by the Peradeniya Botanical Gardens on behalf of the CWGC. The cemetery itself is maintained to an extremely high standard. The landscaping of the grass & the flowers are superb. The initial gravestones as you enter are of the Sri Lankans & are separated according to religions. The gravestones at the top are of foreigners. Sadly, there is no guide to explain things. If you don't have any relations buried here, you won't have any connection by going here. There are many more important things to see in Kandy. But for someone from Kandy, it was good to see the place.

Beautiful place in a quiet corner of Kandy, maintained by the Wargraves Commission.  Well worth it, a great tribute to those who sacrificed their lives to keep us safe.  We met a man who pointed out the various graves from WWII.

This is a place where those who sacrificed their very best lie in quietness. The trees that surround the cemetery stand tall and majestic ; it is a place to reflect upon the sacrifice made, the young men who gave their all for all of us all those years ago.
A small old nicely maintained cementary where soldiers rest in peace. You can stop here for a quick look and feel this place

What a magnificent little military war cemetery. You are greeted by the gardener/caretaker who clearly takes pride in his work. He explains the layout of the groups of headstones of the fallen. To the top on the upper tier by the cross are the British and on the lower ground those of the Commonwealth. A plaque set in the wall explains the attack by the Japanese on the island in 1942 when those laid to rest were killed in action. Well worth a visit - to stop and remember the fallen.

One of the best kept cemeteries in the region. There was a permanent caretaker on site, even though the cemetery, at just over 200 graves is modest in size. There are clear information boards up to provide information which is also a plus. Overall, they have done a really good job with this cemetery.

A well maintained historical place which you give the feeling of old days. If you are around Kandy just go there for a short visit. Because, it will give you a feeling like you were there during world war II. Nice place to visit.
Not far from the city, very peaceful and well maintained cemetery. Can walk around and see the gravestones. Does not require much time to see.

Peaceful reminder of British colonialism close the Temple of the Tooth.   The cemetery is lush and green.  The gravestones are a sad reminder of those who died so far from home and an even sadder reminder of the conquest of Sr Lanka.   Alright if you are in the area, donâ€™t allocate more than 30 minutes to visit though.

When you visit the war cemetery, you get a sympathy feeling. The cemetery is well  maintained. The war cemetery is along the 2nd Rajasinghe Mawatha running along the Mahaweli river and the cemetery is not very far from the turn to its road from Gatabe. I went in the morning and there were three workers cleaning the cemetery. It is little on a incline and that too adds t its beauty. The tress in it and the plants grown near the toms are looking nice. The tomb stones are of one shape and arranged in rows and they coincide along length and even on its breath. Another thing is that diagonally also the tombs are lined. Here lies the soldiers involved in the world war from far countries. May their soles rest in peace.
This honours people who died during the World Wars.A well maintained cemetery. You need about half an hour here.
Beautiful place, well kept and interesting to see. Walk around and read at the stones and read the short memory plaque.

It's a well-maintained and serene resting place. Very impressive with it's well-manicured layout and a gardener tending to the place with passion. The entire area is very neat and it's quite surprising to see the well-cared for tombstones dating back to WW1/2. May they rest in peace!!

Now this place is very impressive! Interesting to see all the different nationalities and so many English that passed away during first and second world wars! The groundskeeper must take some praise because it was beautiful! Go and have a look, you will not be disappointed, max 15-30 mins to have a look around!
Beautiful ranged place with all respect to the people lying down. Wonderfully arranged. Liked the place

So much history contained in such a lovingly laid out and well maintained cemetery. You cannot fail to be moved by the mini-stories that each gravestone represents. So many different nationalities, and such a surprisingly long time period, represented and preserved by the inscriptions. If fortune is with you, the curator will be there, he is very willing to talk about the tales behind each individual monument. Visit it if you can, you won't be disappointed.

This Commonwealth War Cemetery was one of the most beautiful, calm and poignant places I have ever visited. Don't miss it! The words will make you think about what others sacrificed for us. A little piece of history and beautifully maintained.

Our driver introduced us to the gardener who looked after this small but interesting cemetery. Most of the graves are those that were killed when the Japanese bombed Sri Lanka (then Ceylon) in WW2. A very moving place

On a whistlestop tour of the graveyard en route to Kandy to briefly pay our respects to all that perished in WW2. Interesting to know that until this day the British government provides the Â£ for the upkeep of the site, which is a good thing for them to do.

This is a very moving place to visit when you wander round the graves and read the names on the headstones. It also gives an insight into some WW2 history. It is beautifully maintained and well worth a visit.

Beautifully maintained and you can read the story of Ceylon relative to this area during the Second World War. There is a caretaker there who is very helpful and will assist you with information (a 200rps tip is appropriate). 32 RAF aircraft were lost here in 1943 and one section of the cemetery is for the British serviceman - and how young they were. Not to be forgotten.
This is on most tours and perhaps worth a quick look. Don't hang about though there are more interesting places to see.

We always try to seek out a CWGC location when abroad and spend a little time reflecting on the names and history associated with them. This one is only small but is, as they always seem to be, very beautifully tended and maintained. We spoke to the head gardener who gave us a very informative history of it but it was his obvious love for those whose graves he was tending that struck us as so nice.

This cemetery is a very peaceful escape from the chaos of central Kandy.  It is beautifully looked after.  If you are visiting Kandy, then get your tuk tuk driver to take your here.  15 minutes is enough.

Sri Lanka is a busy hectic place. This is not. Usual excellent maintenance expected of these places, and usual man waiting for tip as expected in this country. Only about 270 headstones from the two Japanese air raids, many nationalities. Go if you are close.
Really beautifully maintained cemetary for those killed during the Japanese invasion of Sri Lanka.Worth a 10min walk around to see all the fallen

Any Commonwealth War Cemetary is worth a visit and this is no exception. Beautifully laid out and so well maintained there is nothing deathly about it. To walk around the lines of stones and see the sacrifices that weâ€™re made is always very sobering and thought provoking.
Kandy was Mountbatten' HQ in WWII and the cemetery is one of three in the island - a total of 2000 British service personnel are buried on the island

No burials but interesting to visit because each of the memorial headstones describes the soldier's position and perhaps rank. Well tendered and the local guy will come over and offer to help. Wothy of half an hour or so.
This cemetery is a quiet place, a charming and a well manicured garden with flowers all around. Very beautiful, very clean and very green!

Worth dropping in as part of a bigger trip but not worth the trouble on a standalone basis. People banging on about how wonderful the Sri Lankans are to maintain it - get it right people - its funded by the Commonwealth War Graves commission. If it was Sri Lankan funded there'd be a foreigners entrance fee on it by now.
This is where all the soldiers that fought in the war are buried. The place is well kept and neat. The grass nicely trimmed.
The cemetery was surprice for me. The athmosphere was nice - sunny morning and cool weather. Informative and nice place on the way to Nuwara.

I was amazed to see how well they have maintained and kept this war cemetery. It is a little bit away from the main town and you can take a tuktuk to reach there. It was really peaceful and nice. It is sad to see such young men giving their lives during the war. Loved this place in Kandy.

This war cemetery is immaculately kept by an attendant whom we were lucky enough to meet, he takes great pride in keeping it beautiful. You can't help but be moved when reading some of the inscriptions, most were killed when the Japanese bombed the harbour.
Beautiful gardens and perfectly maintained which makes a really special place and a peaceful and dignified place to visit.
This is one of the most beautiful cemeteries I've ever seen. It is extremely well tended. A moving place to visit.
Very well maintained gardens and a solemn place to visit. Its a bit off the main road but worth seeking out even to spend a few minutes paying your respects.

We visited this cemetery just before the 11th November and would have lived to have been there for the 11th. This is such a beautiful, peaceful resting place which is kept in pritstine condition by the gardener we met there. He was so knowledgable and knew exactly where each grave was. Such a moving visit
The cemetery is extremely well kept and a very peaceful setting. We was met by the gardener who looks after site who explained a little about some of the graves. Definitely worth a visit.
Yet another place in Sri Lanka marketed well to the tourists. Nothing about this cemetery that differentiates it from rest of the better cemeteries elsewhere.

It is a very solemn place honoring the brave souls who sacrificed their lives in the WW II. This small but beautifully maintained cemetery is the final resting place of soldiers and civilians from many countries. It is a must visit place for all soldiers and civilians.
Not much to see here, but the park is beautifully preserved, so if you're passing stop for a quick look.

The Kandy War Cemetery is a British military cemetery for soldiers of the British Empire who were killed during World War II as well as a soldier who died during World War I. There are 26 of Sri Lankans buried out of 203.The cemetery is very well maintained by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, but it is very sad to see to many graves of so many people who died so young.. This cemetery really is a must-visit when you are in Kandy to pay tribute to those who sacrificed their lives for our future.

A very moving experience to visit this beautifully maintained cemetery. We were given a tour by the head gardener who obviously took great pride in his job. The graveyard has soldiers from India, Sri Lanka, England and Scotland. Many of the young men did not die in combat; Malaria and Cholera took many lives.

Its a very calm and quiet environment. It's not a big place to walk around a lot. But it is well maintained . It doesn't take much time for a person visiting to kandy to go there since it's situated just around 3 km away from kandy city. If your stay in kandy is at The Earl's Regent  then it's on your way to the hotel . You can complete your visit within 45 mins time . Enjoy cheers ðŸ»
the whole visit will take around 15 minutes while you stroll through the Cemetry reading the tombstones.quiet worth the visit.
Beautifully landscaped and maintained. If you are from UK you will be requested to write in the book that's maintained about your experience. Mostly World. War 2 veterans are buried here.
We happened upon this place by accident. It was on way to our hotel. Beautifully kept, like all war graves.

We've visited a few Commonwealth War Graves and are always moved by their sanctuary, sacrifice and dignity. Kandy is one of the smaller but it really is an oasis amidst the mayhem of Kandy and it was a delight to talk to the caretaker (?) about the history of those laid to rest here and his work in maintaining their memory. It was one of the shorter stops in our 10 day schedule but without doubt one of the most enduring. Go see it for yourself and sense the history.

This small cemetery, if you have the time to spare, is in memory of Commonwealth fallen. It is probably the most beautiful cemetery you will ever see with colourful plantings between each well maintained headstone.maintained by one man with plants sourced from the botanical gardens.

Did a visit to this cemetery having visited the older one in town. This is for the loss of life during world war two, British, commonwealth, Italian and others. So well maintained. Details about the attack by the Japanese on the island during WW2. The caretaker is likely to approach and provide some information, again for a small tip. well worth 30 minutes of anybody's time for those that made the ultimate sacrifice.

Whist driving around Kandy, our driver brought us here. Unfortunately, the gates were locked but the kindly caretaker had spotted us and opened the gate. A peaceful half hour was spent in this beautifully maintained cemetery.
A little triumph for the Commonwealth Graves Commission, this beautiful serene place really is a bit of the Empire abroad. Even more poignant as my wife's father had served in Ceylon during WW2.

We had our own rental car so getting there was not a problem but it took around half an hour. The cemetry is in beautiful grounds and very well tended. The caretaker kindly introduced himself and shared a couple of intetesting facts his English and our lack of his language prevented a further insight.
There are around 200 buried consists mostly of British soldiers. It's a small place and you can complete it within 40 minutes. There are no entry fees, the environment is green and clean.
This war cemetery is well worth a visit to pay respects to the dead of WW2. It's very well maintained and you can learn of some of the events that caused these sad losses.

I visited this place few years back. The surrounding is very beautiful with perfect gardening. As you walk among the memorial stones and start reading their names, you will definitely feel some kind of peace in mind and great honor for these war heroes. It is a very silent walk but you would love to spend time. Recommend to allocate at least 1-2 hours time here, so you can enjoy it without a rush.
Lovely and well kept cemetery paying tribute to the fallen of the second world war. A bit of the beaten track. We pulled over after our driver suggested we walk around.

The cemetery is absolutely immaculate! It's a wonderful tribute to those that served in the forces during those bitter years. The caretaker was really helpful and explained the history and showed us around. Lovely quiet spot to respect our ancestors!

It's good to know that those who served are remembered properly. Very well and respectfully maintained. Kids were suitably touched. Caretaker showed us around and did not hang around for a tip. Well worth a respectful visit.
Lovely place. Neatly maintained. A MUST visit place in Kandy!! This place has a lot of history to look up. Resides in a peaceful environment.
Perfect for photographers and people who love solitude. Thick green landscape makes this place a special one. Perfect for couple photoshoot
If you have relatives in the second world war then you must visit if you are in the area to keep the memory alive.
well worth the visit and went as part of an organised tour with Mercury Direct. (although the visit was an impromptu one)

Definitely worth a side track from the Tooth Temple, along the way you'll also pass a newly constructed and spotless toilet (donated by a Chinese construction  company). Like other reviewers have said, the caretaker Mr Charles Carmichael is extremely knowledgeable and has been there since the cemetery restoration works. All of the tombstones were shipped in from England and Scotland and some of the inscriptions have been worn out with time, but Mr Carmichael has them memorised by heart (and all the inscriptions on every grave are also catalogued in the little museum which is also worth a visit).
Impeccably maintained cemetery that keeps War memory alive. Moving feelings occurs as you stroll around the tumbs and see how young most of these men were.
Small beautifully kept war grave tended with loving care by the gardener who is very proud of his responsibilities which is heart warming. Peaceful and quiet amongst the hustle and bustle of Kandy
Immaculate gardens and an interesting wander around the headstones. Peace and harmony in the mayhem of Kandy. Lest we Forget.
Not much to say. Visited on a Thursday and it was closed. Got some nice photos because I held my phone over the security bars.

This is a beautiful place to pause and reflect.  This features graves from the Second World War.  The gardens are beautifully manicured. Details of the service personnel who died can be located via the British war graves commission in Berkshire.

The gardens here are just amazing and the over 200 grave sites honoured and well cared for. You have over 7 different countries including Sri Lankans, Africans, Canadians, British, Italians though no Aussies even though we did fight here. Saddest part a large majority died mid 1945 and most were in their early twentys.
A moment of reflection in a wonderful holiday. This beautifyl kept cemetery is a reminder of the many nationalities that died in WW11 in Sri Lanka. A moment of calm and reflection in a a busy city..
it is good place which is situated in Kandy .One of the tourist attraction now a days:)Good if you can add it to your ravel tub.

Formerly known as Pitakande Military Cemetery, it was acquired originally by the military authorities, and was subsequently taken over by the Commission as a permanent war cemetery. The Army Graves Service transferred to this cemetery service war graves from Divatalawa Boer Military Cemetery; (including graves which had previously been moved from Divatalawa Camp Cemetery and Diyakaduwa Cemetery and from Bandarawala in the Punjab); Galkissa General Cemetery; Ihala Vitiyala Burial Ground; Kandy Civil Cemetery; Kollonawa Burial Ground; Kotagala Forest Creek Cemetery; Mahaiyawa Cemetery; Murugampola Cemetery; Rawatawatte General Cemetery, Moratura; Tibotugoda Etakorasa Cemetery and Trincomalee Hindu and Buddhist Cemetery. The Special Memorial commemorates a naval man known to have been buried in the cemetery but whose grave could not be precisely located. It bears the superscription "Buried near this spot". There is 1 Commonwealth burial of the 1914-1918 war and a further 196 Commonwealth burials of the 1939-1945 war commemorated here. In addition there are 4 Foreign National and 2 non world war burials.

The place was like an English garden. Not easy to get there since it was on the other side of Kandy hill. Stunning by hand snip lawn, different flowers on each graves among the wavy landscape among small hill was very worthwhile. Need somebody gave plenty of time to patiently wait for our slow visiting activities. Thanks for Matheesha tour and Jagath for willingly add more this place to ours trip.
This is a very nicely laid out, well-maintained cemetery.  It was interesting to see the different groups represented, but I wouldn't consider it a must-see.

We paid a short visit when in Kandy. It's worth stopping to pay your respects to those that have died in world wars. Some of the gravestones had very moving inscriptions. The entire garden is impeccably maintained and is free to enter.

Nice place, many foreigners visited the place while we were there. Excellent maintenance. Open environment, very relaxing. Fenced and Gated, kept open during the day. No entrance fee. Beautiful surroundings. Right opposite is the river.  Good place to just drop in while you are passing by. Ideally situated in a Tourist area, with classic hotels.
just stopped on the way past, well preserved and maintained nice to see some of our soldiers remembered in true style.
it belongs to british people. they wanted to collonised srilanka this cemetry became here one of the result of that so nice calm place visit it

Please, if you are visiting Kandy take time to visit this beautifully kept cemetery which honours those brave people that died so that we could live in a free world. Take time to visit each grave and read some of the lovely words on the stones. As an ex-service man myself I found this quite an emotional visit but this place is a fitting, peaceful resting place for them, thank you all.
Visited this cemetery in November to respect the war dead. Gardens are quiet & beautiful, the staff who take care of these gardens do a wonderful job.
Very near to Royal Botanical Garden of  Peradeniya.no entrance fees.you can spend lot of time and can think about reality of life
Very calming place. You can see the respect people have for fallen in world war 2. We met some people there who explained us some of the history. If you have an option pay a visit.
The place is calm, soothing and oozing history..its lonely and it adds to the environment...not only the graves of British soldiers but that off Brits who helped build the town also are kept here

A beautifully kept cemetery, its fairly small and will only take most people ten minutes to visit to pay your respects, the atmosphere is calm, quiet and ideal for reflection, it can bring a tear to the eye. Worth the visit if passing near by.
Was a site to see on our tour. The site is very well kept and shows a tremendous amount of respect for those who gave their lives for their country.

I was really pleased to see that this made the top of the list of things to do in Kandi. Similar to other reviewer, after feeling like everyone in the country of Sri Lanka was trying to separate me from my money, traveling to the cemetery was a peaceful experience. As the pictures show, the location is extremely well kept and the surroundings quiet. Its a great place to go an contemplate the heroes of the past.

Always touching to see the graves of young men and women who have died for their country. This is a peaceful, well kept garden near a river, about 4kms from Kandy. Unfortunately, a lot of the recent reviews have mistaken this cemetery for the Garrison Cemetery in Kandy behind the temple, which is a fantastic tribute to pioneering families. I recommend both.

I agree with the positive comments others have made.  Sobering to see that few survived to the age of 40 even tho (I was told) most were experienced in India. Directions.  From the Temple of the (never to be seen!!) Tooth, there is a connecting gate: follow the path to the right on and up.  From the north side of the lake, walk past the Temple and turn left immediately after it and it's a short walk up to the cemetery.  The longest option is to enter the Ministry of Archaeology grounds to the left (west) of the Temple, past a small Temple on the left, go to the end, turn sharp left and the take the turn on the right sign posted to the Temple of the Tooth and keep walking upwards.  The first and the third routes will take you past the Museum of Buddhist History.

an excellent calm and tranquil location over the river with a great view. This place is well maintained for hits age, where British soldiers and comrads of war time are laid to rest over 50 years ago.

Very peaceful setting, well maintained and the gardener who has worked here for many years is able to offer information, history and stories of the well known visitors who have supported the cemetery.

Having read some of the reviews on here I feel some people don't understand why these places exist? It is a beautiful cemetery and is kept very well. The caretaker speaks excellent english and is very forthcoming with stories, help etc. It is a smaller commonwealth cemetery however it is perfectly formed. The way it is designed is beautiful, if you stay long enough you will see the sun always shines on the main monument. For those who can't find the history there is a large plaque on the wall under the main monument explaining the history behind it. If you are someone who likes to pay respect to our fallen heroes and service men (also there are graves for support staff who weren't servicemen) then it is worth the visit. It's  a moving site and worth the visit.

Beautiful kept and amazing to visit the lawn and gardens as well as the graves are looked after so well. Being Australian I was proud to say we had visited it. It is a little out of the way of the main centre of Kandy but if you catch a Tuk Tuk there it is very cheap. Not big but well worth seeing.

I've never seen a war cemetery in such beautiful condition! The staff here do a fabulous job, making this cemetery a pleasure to visit for the manicured gardens alone. It's small and doesn't take very long to walk around. It's intriguing to note the variety of ethnicities keen to fight for the Commonwealth! We walked here from our accommodation in primrose gardens so, for us, included a nice walk. I wouldn't say it's a must see, but if you're in the area, it's nice to wander around and be moved by the care for the deceased or, perhaps, it's the love of exquisite gardening...
Very neatly kept place. Quite interesting especially for Historians and for people interested in World War 2.

We visited the cementary during our trip to Kandy. The caretaker noticed us walking through and came to hand us a flyer. When a downpour started he came to find us with an umbrella and started chatting to us in the process. He then proceeded to guide us through the whole cementary pointing out specific graves and stories. Due to the rain we visited a bit longer than planned but it was certainly well worth it, there is also a little museum hut that the caretaker will happily open so people can go and look at the photographs displayed in there. Entrance is free but there is a donation box at the gate, I do hope that visitors contribute a few rupees in appreciation of this well looked after sombre place and the lovely caretaker who has been doing his job passionately for the last 18 years.
A very good place to spend awhile wondering around the headstones. It is immaculately kept and easy to get to.
It was good to see that the fallen from WWII are still remembered. The curator was very helpful in telling us about some of the graves
Pay your respects to those who paid the ultimate price. The commonwealth war graves commission are doing an excellent job of looking after this site
Not far from town along the river. Well maintained small cemetary and particulary highly spoken of by Sri Lankan people
Peaceful and respectful monument to the fallen. This a good place for a short stop to contemplate the suffering of those before us and what they paid for our freedoms. It is very well maintained.

Such an amazingly well tended memorial amongst a beautiful setting for those that lost their lives in the Second World War, the majority of UK origin from age 21 to 56. The mainly uniform gravestones stood proud and the historical plaque at the far side gave a succinct history. Well worth a visit to escape the hustle and bustle of the centre.
in sri lanka we have 3 commonwealth war cemetery ,its colombo ,Tricomali ,and kandy  ,this is beautiful and respectful place to see
This is a just a beautiful place to stop and wander around.  They have kept it really clean and fresh.  I found it a nice place to stop and think.

I came here on recommendation of a local I met earlier today. I knew little of this place and had to pay for a tuk tuk to get here but in the end id say it was well worth it. The place is beautiful a tall order for a cemetery. It's well maintained and this is a fitting resting place and memorial for those who died for Britain and Sri Lanka. It's free so if possible I'd say it's well worth a visit
Beautifully maintained and moving, and staffed by helpful and devoted workers. It is a quiet, thought provoking sanctuary.
Beautiful but small . Its closed by the botanical garden and its free of charge.  Its nothing special but if you are at this part of the town, its worth a visit.
Beautiful and humbling in equal measures. We met the gardener who gave us a little tour and gave us some interesting information.

This is a lovely peaceful place, no entrance fee and completely empty when we went there in the middle of the afternoon. We did this as part of a day in a Tuktuk exploring the non-central temples which was fantastic. Feels very western but far more beautiful and calm than you would find in the UK.
not enough graves, should put more backpackers in there, who ruin kandy completely with their rudeness, stupidity and ignorance.
Very interesting and thought provoking visit. Educational for the children to see what others sacrificed. The cemetery was keep clean and appeared to be well looked after. Well worth a visit.
well worth a visit not far from the Kandy temple, just behind it in fact, well worth a visit whilst visiting the main temple.

Commonwealth war cemetery is located at Deveni (2) Rajasinghe mawatha in Kandy â€“ Peradeniya Road It is not a large garden, It is  one of the most beautifully landscaped & maintained war cemeteries in the world. If you can spend at least one hour to see this, You can learn interesting history lesson.

We only drove to that place and left without entering as it seemed shut. Most of the place is visible from the road and one can make out that its well maintained. But no idea about the history / story behind the place.
Immaculately kept Commonwealth war graves. Local gardener who maintains the plots so well will give you a tour. Very moving. Worth a trip to get some perspective on the sacrifices of WW2.
Nice place to be, quite calm beautiful. Its very easy to go there. I would like to say this place is a echo friendly green place

A tranquil thought provoking place that is maintained beautifully. lf you manage to see the gardener he will tell you the history behind some of the gravestones - such young people to have died so far away from home..............
Loads of history to be heard and seen. Remembering the dead makes you feel sad, for their suffering.
Could be maintained better since it is a war memorial. The place should look a bit more pleasant and soothing with better gardens and lawns.

The cemetery is managed by the Royal Botanical Garden , it wasn't part of our plan but we were offered to visit and we didn't regret it , the cemetery itself is picturesque and the information provided gives you a great insight about the tension during the world war ... really enjoyed the visit and RIP for all the soldiers

We found this by accident on our way from our hotel into Kandy. As my husband was in the forces we stoped to see it. A beautifully maintained place with a tranquil atmosphere. Good just to pause and reflect. Lovely to see that it has been so well maintained.
We saw this on our way to the hotel and located in a by route from the the main road. Nice landscape, and good for history lovers .

This cemetery of victims of the World War II is a very tranquil and insightful place. It has rows of similar tombstones, divided into 3 groups: Sri Lankan, European (mostly British) including African Corps, and Indian. The place is situated on a hillside, which allows a good overview of all the tombs, as well as a picturesque view. The caretaker gave me detailed information about the cemetery, the main events that caused most of deaths, and some of the people buried there, filling the visit with historical context.
The War Cemetery was such a lovely place to visit. Was located outside of Kandy so you will need to get a tuk tuk. A good place to sit and appreciate the wonderfully maintained gardens.
this cemetery is very well kept & a poignant memorial to the troops from the 2nd world war! A lovely peaceful setting to allow quiet reflection in a fitting surrounding.

We travelled outside Kandy to visit this well tended cemetery and were pleased that we had made the effort. A Kingfisher perched on top of the central cross contemplating his crab lunch which was firmly held in his beak.
Stumbled on the Commonwealth War Cemetery accidentally, but was worth the stop.  Beautiful grounds and a great chance to learn a bit about the role Sri Lanka played in WWII.
Just a lovely oasis of calm outside a hectic city. Think this is also the Kandy Garrison cemetery. Beautifully kept
Almost drove straight past it. Well worth stopping and stretching the legs and admiring the beauty of this place and reading some of the history on the hhead stones.

Great view. very peaceful spot to reflect and learn about history of Sri Lanka and WW2. I learned there were soldiers from East Africa Corps, British, Canadian, Sri Lankan, Muslims and even one American who fought for the Canadian Air Force.
A very well kept cemetery surrounded by beautiful trees. So sad to see young British persons buried so far from their loved ones.

Not many people seemed to know about it and it was only when we showed a tourist information person a photo that we got anywhere. It is off the old road to/from Kandy and it is good to ask for the Earls Regent Hotel and then is probably a 20min, flat walk from the main rd. We managed to do it on public buses.

It seems crazy to write a review about a cemetery but I'm very glad we paid a visit and discovered that there were graves from so many different nationalities who lost their lives whilst stationed in Sril Lanka. I had no idea that allied troops had suffered losses during the Second World War and it is heartening to see that the cemetery is so well maintained.
It is well kept cemetery as are all the Commonwealth War Cemeteries. The staff that was there was very helpful and spent quite a bit of time explaining about the Cemetery to my husband.

A great stop both to recall the 2nd world war and to visit a beautiful garden.  It is immaculately maintained and the caretaker can give you a bit of history( in broken English). Worth the effort to see.
Clean and calm place, however bit nostalgic and sad... Visited as apart of the Kandy trip in TukTuk provided by hotel

A visit to the Commonwealth War Graves Cemetery in Kandy was not part of our itinerary during our recent trip to Sri Lanka but we instructed our guide to cut out some of the pointless shopping stops and include this in the schedule.  The location in a quiet area of Kandy close to the Botanical Gardens and makes for a beautiful setting as the grounds are exceptionally well maintained.  The local care-taker/gardener greeted us and went out of his way to point out graves which would be of interest to us once he learnt we came from the UK.  Well worth a visit to see the graves stones of so many service men and women and we were happy to pay our respects.
This is a quite beautiful place and so well maintained & kept. Well worth a visit to see so the graves stones of many young men & women who paid the ultimate sacrifice for us
Wow, we stumbled across this and am I glad we did. This was a lovely place and so well kept, we saw 5 men tending the grass and plants. Anybody with relatives buried here should feel very assured.
Nicely maintained..relives old memories..a place to visit and know the contribution of Lankan citizens in the world war 2 ..nice pictures, perfect placement and a must for visitors
very helpful and informative gardeners on site and the grounds were very well maintained. It is a short tuktuk ride from Kandy

A very beautiful, peaceful, well maintained war cemetery, giving a real insight into the role of Sri Lanka in the war. The graves include British, Canadian, African and local servicemen, many of them airmen, gunners or sappers/pioneers (victims of bombing/ air war?), and sailors. There are number of infantrymen from individual units, probably victims of jungle trying on the island? My husband had a long chat with the gardener, who acts as a guide - he heard about the recent visit of Prince Charles, and some moving stories of visits by now elderly relatives. A lovely, quiet spot. We are glad we went to pay our respects.

This is a beautiful my kept garden with very well tended graves. Ashamed to say I never associated Sri Lanka with WW2. Grand to ramble around and sir for a few minutes. However, if you have no special interest it might not be worth a long trip. Could be a little out of the way.
What a beautifully maintained place. So peaceful and worth a visit! Spend a bit of time and look at the headstones, such an insight into those who made the ultimate sacrifice for us!

The gardens are impressive and perfectly kept by the proud gardener, who has created a colourful display of plants around the tombstones. It is a moving experience to visit and a tribute to the War Graves Commission.

this makes for an interesting historical visit for those interested in in war cemetaries. it is kept in excellent condition by the royal botanical gardens staff. it is interesting to see the vast variety of ships and battalions that were involved.
It's well kept, but nothing great. History of the place is very briefly written. Nothing to lose if you don't visit

We stopped off here following a visit to the botanical gardens.  It is a lovely tranquil little cemetery that brings home to anyone who visits it the tender age of those who lost their lives in war.  It was immaculately maintained and is well worth visiting.
We had a very moving visit to the war cemetary, the gardener happily showed us around and explained everything, facts and information. The gardens are beautiful and very well kept.

Its a place many tourist miss or just ignore, but I would say just take 10-15 minutes and enjoy the beauty of the place and remember those brave soldiers. Well kept and very clean. The greenery the added point for photography lovers.
very clean and calm.give a peace to mind and respect,its quite hard to find thedirections but its worth the money guys
A humbling experience in a beautiful location. A wonderfully exotic example of tge fantastic work of the War Graves Commission.
The caretaker gave me a guided tour and knew every name on every grave!  I was very impressed with how well this was kept - it was beautiful

Wonderful location. Maintained to the highest standards.  An interesting cemetery reflecting the nations serving in war time Ceylon. Even more poignant than other cemeteries because of the diverse ages, ranks and origins of the service men and women.

Sombre, beautiful and a reminder of a time far less peaceful. The grounds are beautifully kept and there's an inscription on the wall at the back of the cemetery with more information about the soldiers buried here. Highly recommended.

Difficult to find without a guide as it is away from the centre of Kendy but worth a visit. The cemetery is well maintained and in a very quiet location where respect could be paid to all the brave soldiers who lost their lives.
Not a large facility compared with other cemeteries in places like PNG, Singapore eyc but pleasing to note that it is very well maintained .

It really brings it home to you just how many different people were involved. This was just a quick visit, it was torrential rain when we went, but seemed apt given where we were. The place is immaculately kept.
Our guide stopped here for us to have a quick look. We wouldn't return but it was worth a brief visit.

Our driver took us here when we had meant him to take us to the Garrison cemetery but were glad we got to see it.  The cemetery is beautiful situated in a small bowel and meticulously maintained.  Flowers and shrubs, perfect borders, headstones all straight.  It's a sad place but dignified.
Small, neat and pretty but wouldn't recommend it as a stop for others.  Just like a little garden.  Better go to the Royal Botanical Gardens which has nice trees.

We just came across to this place on the way to our hotel. When we drove pass it was pitch dark and was like any other cemetery feel. But, when we so this place in the first light, it was so very well maintained and could remember the great heroes sleeping inside there now.
We came upon this Cemetry accidentally but was so pleased we did. Pretty little Cemetry extremely well kept and interesting to walk round
in this 100th anniversary of WW1, we visited with 2 ex servicemen, who found the graves of members of their regiments and laid poppies on them. Very moving.
kandy city center shopping busy and lot of food out lets good whether very nice place to be there every things is i liked and i will visit again
Just out of town by tuk-tuk, along a pretty valley. Immaculate lawns with the sound of birds in the trees. WWII cemetery for those who fell defending Sri Lanka from the Japanese.

This is a reminder of the men who fought here for their countries. It is beautifully kept and very interesting, the plaque gives visitors background information. Well worth a visit, especially those from the Commonwealth. May they RIP.
A well-maintained war cemetery for the military casualties of World War II. A place of peace and restfulness.
The Commonwealth War Cemetery is a very well maintained and moving memorial to the brave soldiers, sailors and airmen who gave their lives when defending Sri Lanka during WW2 attacks from Japan.

Hidden away alongside the river a quiet and peaceful place to ponder on lives lost in the wars. The whole cemetery is beautifully manicured and a world away from the hustle and bustle of Kandy town. Well worth a visit

A beautiful tranquil location.  We were on our way out of Kandy  - called in early.  A formal ceremony was schedule for 11.00 but we had to be on our way. The layout is unusual in that it is quite a steeply pitched piece of land so the graves are on tiered levels.  I had not seen graves of buddhist soldiers previously - they feature a stupa instead of a cross or national symbol
We stopped here for just under an hour, it was nice to walk around the grounds and read the head stones and the memorial on the wall and learn a little about how the 2 nd world war affected Sri Lanka

As someone famous once quoted, and having visited many commonwealth cemeteries around the World, we found ourselves here in this very peaceful spot which is easily reached by any Tuk Tuk from Kandy town centre.  The first impression I got was the similarities to this cemetery and the Allied one in Souda Bay on the Island of Crete, both not to small but big enough to walk around and pay your respects, as this little cemetery is also very well kept as it should be. Now, walking around you become acutely aware that there are people from all walks of life who have paid the ultimate price serving their countries just going by the different headstones, and being an ex-serviceman I found this very important too. As in November I'm of to Belgium for the 100th anniversary of WWI and the Menin Gate ceremony as well as exploring the massive battle sites and cemeteries which abound there. Now, great credit must also go to the locals here who work tirelessly keeping this place all neat and tidy, which goes a long way in preserving the past especially in today's uncaring World. I would definitely recommend a visit here in the passing or even when in Kandy...At the going down of the sun..As they say..!

I wa surprised to note the significance of this lace called the colonial war cemetery with a lot of respoect given for the soldiers dead in Great British name. overlooking a very peaceful setting and well maintained by locals.
A very well kept cemetery. Staff were also friendly. Easy access from the road. A nice peaceful place to reflect.
Beautifully looked after and respectfully treated.  Well worth a very quick stop off if you are driving past.
Well maintained and very respectful. A place to remember those who have given us so much today. Easy access.
very calm and remote but in the Kandy city limits as the maps indicate. well maintained. Enjoyed the calm atmosphere. British colonial period war cemetery.

A small cemetery and like all War Graves Commission cemeteries very well tended.  Not large, I believe fewer than 300 graves, the caretaker/gardener knew his stuff!  He had very good spoken English and was able (in our very brief visit) to point out some of the more interesting stories.

I live nearby. As a kid ...some of us explored it at night in the hope of seeing a ghost or two. All we saw was rabbits and an odd fox. If you have had a loved one who died in World War 2 .... do visit this place.

Well maintained..well worth a visit can be combined with a visit to the  Botanical gardens as it is just up the road. The young caretaker spoke good English and was well informed and shared some interesting stories of the history which he had collected from various family members who have visited the graves of the Allied soldiers. We learnt a lot about Sri lanka's involvement in the 2nd world war.
Irrespective of your level of interest in military history this quiet corner of a foreign land is a well kept reminder of the price paid in the journey to the modern Sri Lanka we see today.
Immaculately tended and very serene - and almost forgotten. Pay your respects if you are in Kandy, its a lovely spot.

We came upon this place by accident whilst waiting for my wife's new ring to be sized.  It is beautifully kept, well done to the people who do this.  We spoke to the attendant that day and signed the book.  We were glad to have been here and only spent about 30-60 mins but it was peaceful, moving and kept beautiful in respect of the fallen.
Worth the visit to spend a quiet half hoour remembering the fallen of many nations, calm and peraceful break away from the city bustle

I visited to search for history of my grandfather. The grounds are kept so well and to see such a mix of all those who had died from the previous wars, from whatever country was touching and unexpected. The groundsman were very friendly and a donation was given to maintain the upkeep. Very thought provoking
It's not an attraction. I visit Ypres each year and am humbled to see any war graves wherever I visit. And this was well kept and respectful. Thank you.
Nice peaceful location, very well kept & looked after. Split into sections, small & compact but so well maintained.

We were lucky enough to be shown this cemetery by the caretaker who was retiring that week after over 40 years of tending the cemetery. He told us stories of the men buried there. The place was immaculate, peaceful and you felt was tended with real respect for those buried there. The retiring caretaker was very sad to be leaving and we hope his replacement will do as good a job.
This is a typically well tended War graves site. There always seem to be helpful people around in Sri Lanka. We were guided by the caretaker who was both knowledgeable and interesting

Very nice and quiet place. You can see tombs of soldiers from different countries and religions, all from different backgrounds. There is a big staff working there and the place is very well maintained.
away from the city and the busy local traffic lies this quiet but important little second world war memorial cemetery. it overlooks the river and is well goomed by labourers seen.

The Commonwealth War Cemetery on Dewani Rajasinghe Mawatha in Kandy is a well maintained green cemetery in the heart of town. It is a place to visit for the traveler who sees in tragedy, hope. In this place as you read the epitaphs of men who had laid down their lives, almost all, have died so far from their homes, you feel the presence of that great emotion which bring a sadness and balance in our lives. Those with a sense of history would appreciate this brief break to reflect;  and to take hope in such great sacrifice which gave their countrymen another day. Not for all - but special for some

If you dobt have a car with a driver who knows where this place is located, dont even bother. Got lost even though i was using gps and google maps. You see that is ought to be 60 meters away but will never find a way into the area it is supposed to be in. Local tooktooks had no clue either
colonial war cemetery where lots of british war dead are buried. welkl maintained and in a lush greenery. the view is amazing with the river flowing by.
Moving place. Do not miss out on stopping by here, and remember the fallen of the second World war. Peaceful experience.
People with any interest in history might find this little cemetery moving and be impressed by the variety of nationalities who died helping the Allied effort in WW2.

If you a history buff, if you are looking for a peace and quiet or if you want to know about Sri Lanka then this is a good place. The War cemetery has the graves, the names and some of the history. Extremely well maintained and a place for just wandering through and thinking - really delightful

needed to vsit this place as my blood relations were buried in this place and is a place of hsotical significance for me personaly. well maintained and in a quiet location overlooking the large river. be ware thouh the clesaners keep expecting a tip.

Very calm location over looking the river. well maintained colonial war cemetary. The view of the mountain range is amazing. on the way there are a few delightful small restaurants which could be worth trying.

The caretaker kindly showed us around the cemetery and after working there for 40 years, he has met many relatives and acquired a lot of information regarding the unfortunate soldiers/chefs who died there/nearby. We are in our mid-20's and it was strange to see so many gravestones with ages younger than own. The garden is beautifully maintained and this is definitely worth stopping at (especially if you are staying at Cinnamon Citadel Hotel which is really close by)

A gardener/caretaker took us round and told us stories about the poor souls buried here. It was all very moving as so many were so young. The tributes from families were very touching especially when you consider that these men died so far from home. Worth a visit if you're interested. It's beautifully maintained by a small group of men. The one who showed us round had worked there for over 20 years and knew lots of stuff which he's proud to show off (we gave him a tip of course).
Beautifully kept Commonwealth war cemetery. The custodian is clearly proud of his domain, and rightly so. Makes one stop and think.
Beautiful site but quite difficult for our Tuktuk driver to find. The gate was locked but the tops of the railings on the left have been removed so it is an easy climb over.
Like all commonwelath graves this is beautifully laid out ,maintained  and a sombre history of man, in the last century . If you have a small time to spare this is worth a visit on your itinerary

As a former soldier I never miss an opprotunity to visit such places which always make me sad. Looking at the names of some of those who perished in the second world war and afterwards from injuries sustained, there were British names, African names and names of Ceylonese local people who dies fighting on the British side. Also, there were the graves of Italian soldiers/sailors (I'm not sure) who are buried alongside the others. Given honour and respect the only difference is that the edge of the headstone is cut away on two sides to show they were on the other side. Nevertheless, a fine memorial to men and women who left home and loved ones never to return.
